newsitem.title: JAPAN: LME seen consolidating, but nickel rally not over.
newsitem.headline: LME seen consolidating, but nickel rally not over.

text.p: Nickel prices are likely to climb further on the London Metal Exchange (LME) as a strike at Inco Ltd continues, while copper is expected to take a break after recent rises, traders said on Wednesday.
"Nickel will remain volatile, but it might test the next resistance at $7,250 (a tonne)," said a trader at a Japanese trade house. "It depends on what U.S. funds do with their short positions."

Traders said news of a 20 percent production increase by Russia's Norilsk, the world's largest nickel manufacturer, had been expected sooner or later, while they were watching carefully the strike at Inco's Sudbury facility in Canada.
About 4,670 unionised workers at Inco, the world's second largest nickel maker, went on strike on Tuesday after voting down a tentative contract agreement reached on Friday.
Company and union officials said they did not know when talks would resume.
"We understand Inco has stocks for one or two months," said another Japanese trader. "But if the strike continues, it will have to purchase nickel from outside."
At 0205 GMT, three-month LME nickel was quoted in Asian trade at $7,170/200 a tonne, little changed from Tuesday's close at $7,180 in London, up $155 from the previous day.
Three-month copper rose to $2,491/96 a tonne from $2,479 at the close in London, and aluminium climbed to 1,586/78 from $1,578.

"Although copper remains in an upward trend, it needs some kind of consolidation after the latest straight-line advance," said one trader, who added that aluminium might face even stronger pressure after falling through support earlier this week at $1,600.
"In the near term, aluminium might test the $1,560-1,550 level," the trader added.
